Award.AwardTitle: Targeted MSP: The University at Buffalo/Buffalo Public Schools (UB/BPS) Interdisciplinary Science and Engineering Partnership

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Interdisciplinary Science and Engineering Partnership (ISEP) is led by the University at Buffalo, a member of the State University of New York system, and includes as core partners the Buffalo Public Schools, Buffalo State College and the Buffalo Museum of Science. Supporting partners include Praxair Technology, Inc., Roswell Park Cancer Institute, Hauptman-Woodward Medical Research Institute, the Western New York Service Learning Coalition, and the Buffalo Public Schools District Parent Coordinating Committee.

The focus of ISEP is the critical middle school experiences of students in science and engineering as they transition to high school. The project utilizes an innovative approach to teacher professional development among 12 high-needs urban schools (including "feeder" middle schools and their corresponding high schools) via courses and interdisciplinary research experiences, development of science and technology classroom materials that are aligned with state science learning standards, and inquiry-based curricula. The ISEP also combines novel mentoring approaches and expanded professional learning communities to build leadership and resources for improving science education in high-needs/high-potential urban schools. The learning communities cultivate mentoring relationships involving middle and high school teachers and students, University at Buffalo and Buffalo State College STEM faculty, education faculty, undergraduate students and graduate students, volunteer STEM professionals, and/or parents.

A key program component is the development of a successful mechanism to integrate the latest scientific and engineering research approaches into the experience base of middle and high school teachers. "Research Experiences for Teachers" are widespread across the ISEP with teachers involved in interdisciplinary team-based research programs that focus not only on the research experience, but also on the development of classroom materials that are aligned with learning standards and draw from multidisciplinary approaches. Approximately 48 Buffalo Public Schools teachers each year have the opportunity to access cutting edge research through multiple science and engineering tracks. The ISEP team, which includes principals, links these research experiences to intensive leadership development training, in which teachers align challenging science courses and curricula with national and New York State Learning Standards, focusing on increasing the number of inquiry experiences for students. Ultimately, the teachers enhance their mentoring skills, learn to form expanded learning communities of science educators within their schools, and impact their entire school culture.

ISEP is conducting educational research on the processes and conditions in which science teachers develop interdisciplinary science inquiry knowledge, and how this knowledge may be translated into interdisciplinary pedagogical content knowledge (PCK) that ultimately improves student science learning. Thus, the research questions for the ISEP are: (1) What are science teachers' conceptions of interdisciplinary science inquiry? How do their conceptions change through intensive summer research and ongoing professional developments? (2) How do science teachers translate interdisciplinary science inquiry experiences and understanding gained in university research laboratories into their classroom inquiry instructional practices, i.e., how do science teachers develop interdisciplinary science inquiry PCK? and (3) How do professional learning communities support teacher development of interdisciplinary science inquiry PCK? Findings produced through ISEP are being disseminated throughout the district via a well-organized science teachers network, regionally and statewide using NYLearns.org, through a project website, and through presentations and publications via regional and national venues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Interdisciplinary Science and Engineering Partnership (ISEP) with Buffalo Public Schools was established as a comprehensive program in using interdisciplinary science and engineering research as a means to enhance teacher pedagogical content knowledge (PCK) through professional development. ISEP’s program is supported by an ecosystem model of collaborative participation including the Buffalo Public Schools, the University at Buffalo (SUNY), SUNY Buffalo State College, the Buffalo Museum of Science, Praxair Corporation, the BPS District Parent Coordinating Council and other corporate and community partners.

ISEP also provides human resources such as science and engineering Ph.D. students, undergraduate service learning students and corporate scientists and engineers as STEM mentors in support of implementation of teacher professional development in classrooms, after school programs and summer STEM learning activities for students in Buffalo Public Schools (BPS). BPS serves a diverse population of over 32,000 students with over 80% of students living in poverty and struggling in academic achievement. ISEP was established with private foundation funding in 2005, and was funded by the NSF Math Science Partnership program in 2011 with the following research questions.

  • What are science teachers’ conceptions of interdisciplinary science inquiry? How do their conceptions change through intensive summer research and ongoing professional developments?
  • How do science teachers translate interdisciplinary science inquiry experiences and understanding gained in university research laboratories into their classroom inquiry instructional practices, i.e. how do science teachers develop interdisciplinary science inquiry PCK?
  • How do professional learning communities (PLC’s) support teacher development of interdisciplinary science inquiry PCK?
  • What are the processes of STEM students developing understanding of interdisciplinary science inquiry and abilities to communicating science to middle and high school science teachers and students?

 

From September 2011 until February 2018, nearly two hundred teachers participated in summer professional development and were supported by Ph.D. students, undergraduate service learning students, faculty at higher education institutions, parents and corporate partner staff. Science, technology, special education and English as New Language teachers participated in professional development. Each year, approximately five thousand students from twelve schools in BPS were affected by ISEP PD and classroom support by ISEP Ph.D. and service learning students. Approximately 100 teachers also participated during the academic year professional development to follow up the summer support. Professional development opportunities included work in interdisciplinary research laboratories, summer workshops, some including students from BPS, specially designed courses and research in corporate laboratories. Nearly 100 STEM Ph.D. students participated in at least one year of residence in a middle or high schools. Over 300 service learning students and volunteers worked in classrooms, after school programs and summer camps. Many of the Ph.D and undergraduate service learning students spent multiple years participating in ISEP. Many of the service learning undergraduates were awarded fellowships and scholarships where the ISEP experience was significant in their professional development. Each summer expanded PLCs developed collaborative efforts among groups of teachers, with an emphasis of coordination between middle and high school teachers and within interdisciplinary STEM fields.

The Buffalo Museum of Science was a central component to helping with strategies for parent/family involvement in ISEP. While ISEP benefitted from input from parent leadership groups, such as the Buffalo District Parent Coordinating Committee (DPCC) and later efforts with the Buffalo Parent Teacher Organization, it was grass roots efforts with parents in each school where ISEP was involved with teachers that bore fruit.  Parents of ISEP students developed an annual Student Science Summit held each year at the Museum on a Saturday in March. Students from all ISEP schools demonstrated experimental work they were involved in in the classroom with support from ISEP teachers.  Additionally, the ISEP parent group hosted an annual social justice meeting with invited speakers. Parents were involved in a Parent PLC with annual retreats and planning sessions. The Museum of Science provided free family memberships to all ISEP participating parents, in addition to stipends for parents who advised the ISEP program.  Parent involvement in ISEP provided strength in community knowledge of the ISEP program.

A series of peer reviewed papers and presentations at international conferences were produced from six Ph.D. students in science education. These papers examined the impacts of teacher PCK and how that improvement in PCK translated into student performance. Another set of papers examined the effects of participation on Ph.D. and undergraduate service learning students.  The research papers provided strong quantitative and statistically significant results that validated the model of teacher professional development with wrap around support in the classroom and after school programs on improved  student learning. One aspect that was unique was that middle school students could tell the difference between teachers in their school who were involved in ISEP and those who were not, by the nature of the classroom work and hands on inquiry and laboratory work.
